TITLE: Configuring TracerProvider with gRPC Exporter in Python
DESCRIPTION: Python code to set up the TracerProvider with a gRPC exporter for OpenTelemetry. It creates a resource, sets up the tracer provider, and adds a span processor with the OTLP exporter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/observability/opentelemetry/sentry.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from opentelemetry import trace
from opentelemetry.sdk.resources import Resource
from opentelemetry.sdk.trace import TracerProvider
from opentelemetry.exporter.otlp.proto.grpc.trace_exporter import OTLPSpanExporter
from opentelemetry.sdk.trace.export import BatchSpanProcessor

resource = Resource.create(attributes={"service.name": "faststream"})
tracer_provider = TracerProvider(resource=resource)
trace.set_tracer_provider(tracer_provider)
exporter = OTLPSpanExporter(endpoint="http://localhost:4317")
processor = BatchSpanProcessor(exporter)
tracer_provider.add_span_processor(processor)
```

TITLE: Configuring SASL OAuth Bearer Authentication with SSL/TLS in FastStream (Python)

SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/kafka/security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import ssl
from faststream.security import SASLOAuthBearer
from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

ssl_context = ssl.create_default_context()
ssl_context.check_hostname = False
ssl_context.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE

broker = KafkaBroker(
    "localhost:9092",
    security=SASLOAuthBearer(
        ssl_context=ssl_context,
    ),
    sasl_oauth_token_provider=your_token_provider,
)
```

TITLE: Testing FastAPI StreamRouter with TestClient
DESCRIPTION: Example of testing a FastAPI application with a StreamRouter using TestClient. The StreamRouter can be mocked for testing purposes using the patch_broker context manager.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/integrations/fastapi/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from fastapi import FastAPI
from fastapi.testclient import TestClient
from faststream.kafka.fastapi import KafkaRouter
from faststream.kafka.test import TestKafkaBroker

router = KafkaRouter("localhost:9092")
app = FastAPI(lifespan=router.lifespan_context)
app.include_router(router)


@router.subscriber("test_topic")
async def consume(body: str) -> None:
    print(body)


def test_app():
    with TestKafkaBroker(router.broker) as test_broker:
        with TestClient(app) as client:
            response = client.get("/")
            assert response.status_code == 200
```

TITLE: Watching and Retrieving Objects from Object Storage in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to watch for new files in an Object Storage bucket and retrieve their content. It uses the ObjectStorage annotation to access the current bucket.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/nats/jetstream/object.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream.nats.annotations import ObjectStorage

@broker.subscriber("example-bucket", obj_watch=True)
async def handler(filename: str, object_storage: ObjectStorage):
    assert filename == "file.txt"
    
    obj = await object_storage.get(filename)
    content = await obj.get_data()
    
    assert content == b"Hello World!"
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with Falcon
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to integrate a FastStream broker with the Falcon framework. It creates a custom FastStreamComponent that manages the broker's lifecycle within the Falcon application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/integrations/frameworks/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import json

from falcon.asgi import App
from falcon.asgi.app_helpers import RouteHandler

from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker


async def init():
    await broker.start()


broker = KafkaBroker()


class FastStreamComponent:
    def __init__(self, broker):
        self.broker = broker

    async def process_startup(self, scope, event):
        await self.broker.start()

    async def process_shutdown(self, scope, event):
        await self.broker.close()


class HelloResource:
    async def on_get(self, req, resp):
        resp.text = json.dumps({"greeting": "Hello, world!"})


app = App(middleware=[FastStreamComponent(broker)])
app.add_route("/", HelloResource())


class WelcomeHandler(RouteHandler):
    async def on_get(self, req, resp):
        resp.text = json.dumps({"greeting": "Welcome!"})


welcome = WelcomeHandler()
app.add_route("/welcome", welcome)
```

TITLE: Retrieving Broker Server Configuration in FastStream AsyncAPI Generation
DESCRIPTION: The `get_broker_server` function extracts server information from broker configurations, determining the server URL based on the broker type and settings. It handles different broker types including Kafka, RabbitMQ, NATS, Redis, and Pulsar, generating appropriate server URLs based on their connection details.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/asyncapi/generate/get_broker_server.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def get_broker_server(broker) -> tuple[str, dict[str, Any]]:
    """Get broker server info."""
    broker_class = broker.__class__.__name__

    if broker_class.lower() == "kafka":
        bootstrap_servers = broker._bootstrap_servers
        if isinstance(bootstrap_servers, list):
            bootstrap_servers = ",".join(bootstrap_servers)

        return bootstrap_servers, {
            "protocol": "kafka",
            "protocolVersion": "auto",
        }
    elif broker_class.lower() == "rabbitmq":
        return (
            f"{broker._protocol}://{broker._host}:{broker._port}{broker._vhost}",
            {
                "protocol": broker._protocol,
            },
        )
    elif broker_class.lower() == "nats":
        return (
            broker._servers[0] if len(broker._servers) == 1 else str(broker._servers),
            {
                "protocol": "nats",
            },
        )
    elif broker_class.lower() == "redis":
        return (
            str(broker._dsn),
            {
                "protocol": "redis",
            },
        )
    elif broker_class.lower() == "pulsar":
        return (
            broker._url,
            {
                "protocol": "pulsar",
            },
        )

    raise NotImplementedError(f"{broker_class} protocol not supported")
```

TITLE: Complete FastStream Application with Kafka Partition Keys in Python
DESCRIPTION: A complete FastStream application that consumes messages from an input topic and publishes them to an output topic with partition keys. The example demonstrates how to integrate partition keys into Kafka-based applications for optimized message distribution.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/confluent/Publisher/using_a_key.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream import FastStream
from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field


class InputData(BaseModel):
    user_id: str
    payload: str


class OutputData(BaseModel):
    user_id: str
    payload: str
    processed: bool = Field(default=True)


broker = KafkaBroker("localhost:9092")
app = FastStream(broker)


@broker.publisher("output_data")
async def process_message(message: InputData, publish):
    # convert the input message to the output format
    output_message = OutputData(user_id=message.user_id, payload=message.payload)
    
    # publish the message with a key
    await publish(output_message, key=message.user_id)
```

TITLE: Implementing Synchronous Fake Context in Python for FastStream

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def sync_fake_context(cm):
    """Create a fake async context for testing purposes."""
    try:
        yield cm.__enter__()
    finally:
        cm.__exit__(None, None, None)
```

TITLE: Defining LogicSubscriber Class for FastStream Confluent in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the LogicSubscriber class, which is a part of the FastStream Confluent subscriber module. It inherits from BaseSubscriber and implements methods for handling Kafka message subscriptions and processing.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/confluent/subscriber/usecase/LogicSubscriber.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class LogicSubscriber(BaseSubscriber):
    def __init__(
        self,
        *args: Any,
        topic: str = "",
        group_id: str | None = None,
        auto_offset_reset: Literal["earliest", "latest"] = "earliest",
        enable_auto_commit: bool = True,
        max_poll_interval_ms: int = 300000,
        **kwargs: Any,
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.topic = topic
        self.group_id = group_id
        self.auto_offset_reset = auto_offset_reset
        self.enable_auto_commit = enable_auto_commit
        self.max_poll_interval_ms = max_poll_interval_ms

    def setup(self) -> None:
        self.consumer = Consumer(
            {
                "bootstrap.servers": self.client.bootstrap_servers,
                "group.id": self.group_id or uuid4().hex,
                "auto.offset.reset": self.auto_offset_reset,
                "enable.auto.commit": self.enable_auto_commit,
                "max.poll.interval.ms": self.max_poll_interval_ms,
            },
        )
        self.consumer.subscribe([self.topic])

    async def run(self) -> None:
        while True:
            msg = self.consumer.poll(1.0)
            if msg is None:
                continue
            if msg.error():
                if msg.error().code() == KafkaError._PARTITION_EOF:
                    # End of partition event
                    logger.error(
                        "%% %s [%d] reached end at offset %d\n",
                        msg.topic(),
                        msg.partition(),
                        msg.offset(),
                    )
                elif msg.error():
                    raise KafkaException(msg.error())
            else:
                await self.process_message(msg)

    async def process_message(self, msg: Message) -> None:
        await self.call_handle(msg.value(), msg=msg)

    def __del__(self) -> None:
        if hasattr(self, "consumer"):
            self.consumer.close()
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with Aiohttp
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to integrate a FastStream broker with Aiohttp using application startup and cleanup contexts. The broker is connected during application initialization and properly closed during shutdown.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/integrations/frameworks/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from aiohttp import web

from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

broker = KafkaBroker()


async def init():
    await broker.start()


async def close():
    await broker.close()


async def setup_broker(app: web.Application) -> None:
    app.on_startup.append(lambda _: init())
    app.on_cleanup.append(lambda _: close())


async def handle(request: web.Request) -> web.Response:
    return web.Response(text="Hello, world")


app = web.Application()
app.router.add_get("/", handle)
app.on_startup.append(setup_broker)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    web.run_app(app)
```

TITLE: Interrupting Message Processing with AckMessage Exception

SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/redis/streams/ack.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

from faststream.redis import RedisBroker
from faststream.exceptions import AckMessage, NackMessage

broker = RedisBroker("redis://localhost:6379")
app = FastStream(broker)

@broker.subscriber("test-stream")
async def base_handler(body: dict):
    if body["status"] == "success":
        raise AckMessage()
    elif body["status"] == "error":
        raise NackMessage()

    # do some work
    ...

if __name__ == "__main__":

```

TITLE: Running Asynchronous Functions in Python with run_async Utility
DESCRIPTION: The run_async function provides a versatile way to execute asynchronous functions in different contexts. It can handle coroutines, check if they're already running in an event loop, and properly manage the event loop lifecycle based on the execution environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/utils/functions/call_or_await.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def run_async(coroutine: Coroutine[Any, Any, T]) -> T:
    """Run coroutine in current or newly created event loop.

    Args:
        coroutine: Coroutine to run.

    Returns:
        Result of the coroutine execution.
    """
    try:
        loop = asyncio.get_running_loop()
    except RuntimeError:
        loop = asyncio.new_event_loop()
        return loop.run_until_complete(coroutine)
    else:
        if loop.is_running():
            return loop.create_task(coroutine)
        else:
            return loop.run_until_complete(coroutine)
```

from faststream.nats import NatsBroker

async def startup():
    await broker.publish(

        subject="some-subject",
    )


@broker.subscriber("some-subject")
async def handler(msg: dict, logger: Logger):
    logger.info(f"Received: {msg}")

    await broker.publish(
        {"status": "Application ready!"},
        subject="some-subject",
    )

TITLE: Defining Context Class in FastStream Framework
DESCRIPTION: The Context class is a core component of FastStream for managing context-bound variables, tracing, and logging state. It includes attributes for correlation IDs, tracing, context variables, and application state.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/Context.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class Context:
    """FastStream Context state.

    It contains the current state of context variables, tracing and logging.
    """

    correlation_id: str | None = None
    """Message correlation ID"""

    extras: Dict[str, Any] = Field(default_factory=dict)
    """Context variables"""

    call_next_hooks: bool = True
    """Call next hooks flag"""

    call_next_watcher: bool = True
    """Call next watcher flag"""

    scope: Dict[str, Any] = Field(default_factory=dict)
    """FastDepends scope"""
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with FastAPI using NATS StreamRouter
DESCRIPTION: Using FastStream NATS StreamRouter with FastAPI, allowing you to declare message handlers with subscriber and publisher decorators. FastStream integrates with FastAPI's dependency and serialization system, supporting Depends, BackgroundTasks, and other FastAPI tools.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/faststream.md#2025-04-22_snippet_19

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import asyncio
from typing import Annotated

from fastapi import FastAPI, Depends, BackgroundTasks
from faststream.nats.fastapi import NatsRouter

# Define FastAPI app
app = FastAPI(title="My Service")

# Define StreamRouter
nats_router = NatsRouter(
    "nats://localhost:4222",
)

# Define dependency
def get_user_id():
    return "user1"

# Define handler
@nats_router.subscriber("topic1")
async def consume(
    msg: dict,
    tasks: BackgroundTasks,
    user_id: Annotated[str, Depends(get_user_id)],
) -> None:
    tasks.add_task(print, f"Processing message for {user_id}")
    await asyncio.sleep(1)
    print(f"Message processed: {msg}")

# Include StreamRouter in FastAPI
app.include_router(nats_router)
```

TITLE: Using TestApp Class for Testing FastStream Applications in Python
DESCRIPTION: The TestApp class provides utilities for testing FastStream applications by simulating message publishing and consumption. It inherits from AsyncTestClient and implements methods for publishing messages, consuming them, and testing the application behavior.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/redis/TestApp.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class TestApp(AsyncTestClient):
    """TestApp is a test client for the FastStream application.

    It provides methods for publishing messages to the application and consuming
    messages from it.

    ### Example

    ```python
    from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

    broker = KafkaBroker()


    @broker.subscriber("test")
    async def base_handler(body: str):
        return body


    @broker.publisher("test-response")
    @broker.subscriber("test-request")
    async def publisher_handler(body: str, write=...):
        response = await write(body)
        return response


    app = broker.app

    # testing
    from faststream.testing import TestApp

    async def test_app():
        async with TestApp(app) as client:
            # test subscriber
            response = await client.publish("hello", "test")
            assert response == [{"payload": "hello", "handler": base_handler}]

            # test publisher
            response = await client.publish("hello", "test-request")
            assert response == [{"payload": "hello", "handler": publisher_handler}]
            assert client.history == [{"to": "test-response", "message": "hello"}]
    ```
    """

    def __init__(
        self,
        app: _AppType,
        include_in_schema: bool = True,
        **kwargs: Any,
    ) -> None:
        """Initialize a FastStream app for testing.

        Args:
            app: A FastStream app to test
            include_in_schema: Whether to include the app in the OpenAPI schema
            **kwargs: Additional arguments to pass to AsyncClient
        """
        if "debug" not in kwargs:
            kwargs["debug"] = True

        super().__init__(
            app=app,
            include_in_schema=include_in_schema,
            **kwargs,
        )
```

TITLE: Configuring Logger Format in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: The set_logger_fmt function allows setting custom logging formats for different environments (development, production). It configures the logger with specific colors, date formats and patterns based on the environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/log/logging/set_logger_fmt.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def set_logger_fmt(fmt: str | None = None, scope: str = "app", level: int | None = None) -> None:
    """Set logging format.

    `fmt`'s default value is set depending on the environment.
    If `env(ENV_PREFIX + "ENV")` is set to "development" (case-insensitive),
    the default value is `LOG_DEV_FMT`. Otherwise, the default value
    is `LOG_PROD_FMT`.

    Args:
        fmt (str | None): logging format. Defaults to None.
        scope (str, optional): logging scope. Defaults to "app".
        level (int | None, optional): logging level. Defaults to None.
    """
    import logging
    import os
    import sys

    from colorlog import ColoredFormatter

    from faststream.log.formatters import JSONFormatter

    if not fmt:
        fmt = _get_logging_config()["fmt"]

    handler = logging.StreamHandler(sys.stdout)

    if fmt == LOG_DEV_FMT:
        handler.setFormatter(
            ColoredFormatter(
                "%(bold_white)s%(name)-30.30s%(reset)s | "
                "%(log_color)s%(levelname)-8.8s%(reset)s | "
                "%(bold_blue)s%(filename)s:%(lineno)d%(reset)s | "
                "%(log_color)s%(message)s%(reset)s",
                log_colors={
                    "DEBUG": "thin",
                    "INFO": "bold_green",
                    "WARNING": "bold_yellow",
                    "ERROR": "bold_red",
                    "CRITICAL": "bold_red,bg_white",
                },
            )
        )
    elif fmt == LOG_JSON_FMT:
        handler.setFormatter(JSONFormatter())
    else:
        handler.setFormatter(logging.Formatter(fmt))

    if level is None:
        level = _get_logging_config()["level"]

    for cur_handler in logging.getLogger(scope).handlers:
        logging.getLogger(scope).removeHandler(cur_handler)

    logging.getLogger(scope).setLevel(level)
    logging.getLogger(scope).addHandler(handler)
```

TITLE: Publishing Messages to Redis List in Python
DESCRIPTION: This method publishes a batch of messages to a Redis list. It takes the list name and a sequence of messages as parameters, then uses the Redis pipeline to efficiently push all messages to the list.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/redis/publisher/usecase/ListBatchPublisher.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
async def publish(self, list_name: str, messages: Sequence[Any]) -> None:
    async with self.client.pipeline(transaction=False) as pipe:
        for message in messages:
            await pipe.lpush(list_name, message)
        await pipe.execute()
```

TITLE: Parsing NATS Security Credentials in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: The parse_security function is used to process NATS security credentials from various sources including files, dictionaries, and predefined NATSCredentials objects. It validates input types and returns properly formatted security credentials for NATS connections.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/nats/security/parse_security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def parse_security(
    security: Union[Dict[str, str], str, NATSCredentials, None],
) -> Optional[NATSCredentials]:
    """Parse NATS security from files, dict or security object.

    Parameters
    ----------
    security: `typing.Union[typing.Dict[str, str], str, NATSCredentials, None]`
        NATS security credentials, path to CREDS file,
        dict with security params,
        or `None` if not security

    Returns
    -------
    `typing.Optional[NATSCredentials]`
        Security credentials for NATS

    Raises
    ------
    TypeError
        If security has wrong type
    """
    if security is None:
        return None

    if isinstance(security, dict):
        return NATSCredentials(**security)

    if isinstance(security, str):
        return NATSCredentials(nkeys_file=security)

    if isinstance(security, NATSCredentials):
        return security

    raise TypeError(
        "security parameter should be a dict of params, path to creds "
        f"file or {NATSCredentials.__name__} instance",
    )
```

TITLE: Converting Strings to camelCase in Python for FastStream AsyncAPI
DESCRIPTION: This utility function converts a string from snake_case or other formats to camelCase by removing underscores and capitalizing the first letter of each word except the first. It's designed to standardize field naming in API schemas.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/asyncapi/utils/to_camelcase.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def to_camelcase(string: str) -> str:
    """Convert a string to camelcase.

    Args:
        string: String to convert

    Returns:
        String in camelcase
    """
    string_split = string.split("_")
    if len(string_split) == 1:
        return string_split[0]
    return string_split[0] + "".join(word.capitalize() for word in string_split[1:])
```

TITLE: Building RabbitMQ Connection URLs in Python
DESCRIPTION: The build_url function constructs a RabbitMQ connection URL string from various connection parameters including host, port, username, password, and virtual host. It handles URL encoding for special characters and supports both AMQP and AMQPS protocols.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/rabbit/utils/build_url.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def build_url(
    host: str = "localhost",
    port: Optional[int] = None,
    user: Optional[str] = None,
    password: Optional[str] = None,
    virtualhost: Optional[str] = None,
    ssl: bool = False,
) -> str:
    """Build RMQ url from parts.

    Args:
        host: broker host. Default: "localhost".
        port: broker port. Default: None, means 5671 for secured connection
            and 5672 for not.
        user: username to auth. Default: None, means "guest".
        password: password to auth. Default: None, means "guest".
        virtualhost: rmq virtualhost. Default: "/".
        ssl: use SSL for connection or not. Default: False.
    """
    scheme = "amqps" if ssl else "amqp"

    if port is None:
        port = 5671 if ssl else 5672

    if user is None:
        auth = ""
    else:
        if password is None:
            auth = f"{quote(user)}@"
        else:
            auth = f"{quote(user)}:{quote(password)}@"

    if virtualhost is None:
        virtualhost = "/"
    elif not virtualhost.startswith("/"):
        virtualhost = f"/{virtualhost}"

    return f"{scheme}://{auth}{host}:{port}{quote(virtualhost)}"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parsing Redis Security Configuration in Python
DESCRIPTION: This function parses Redis security configuration settings, supporting both password-only and username-password authentication. It accepts various input formats including strings, dictionaries, and specialized security objects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/redis/security/parse_security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def parse_security(
    security: Optional[
        Union[str, Dict[str, str], RedisSecurity, URLSecurity]
    ] = None,
) -> Tuple[Optional[str], Optional[str]]:
    """Parse security object."""
    username: Optional[str] = None
    password: Optional[str] = None

    if security is None:
        return username, password

    # Directly passed RedisSecurity
    if isinstance(security, RedisSecurity):
        return security.username, security.password

    # Directly passed URLSecurity
    if isinstance(security, URLSecurity):
        return security.username, security.password

    # String password
    if isinstance(security, str):
        password = security
        return username, password

    # Dict with username and password
    if isinstance(security, dict):
        username = security.get("username")
        password = security.get("password")
        return username, password

    raise TypeError(f"Unsupported security type: {type(security)}")
```

TITLE: Version Callback Function for FastStream CLI in Python
DESCRIPTION: This function is used to display version information when the --version flag is used with the FastStream CLI. It prints the FastStream package version, Python version, and platform information, then exits the program.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/cli/main/version_callback.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def version_callback(value: bool) -> None:
    """
    Print package version and exit.

    Args:
        value (bool): Flag value.
    """
    if value:
        import platform
        import sys

        from ..__meta__ import __version__

        info = platform.platform()
        print(f"FastStream: {__version__}")
        print(f"Python: {sys.version}")
        print(f"Platform: {info}")
        sys.exit(0)
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with Falcon
DESCRIPTION: Using FastStream MQBrokers with Falcon by starting and stopping them according to the application's lifespan, allowing for message broker interaction in a Falcon web application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/faststream.md#2025-04-22_snippet_13

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import json

import falcon.asgi
from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

broker = KafkaBroker("localhost:9092")


@broker.subscriber("input")
async def handle(msg: str) -> None:
    print(msg)


class Push:
    async def on_get(self, req, resp):
        await broker.publish("Hello World!", "input")
        resp.text = json.dumps({"status": "sent"})
        resp.content_type = falcon.MEDIA_JSON


app = falcon.asgi.App()
app.add_route("/", Push())


# Falcon doesn't support any specific hooks for startup or shutdown,
# so we need to manage the broker differently depending on how you run your app.

# For a typical ASGI server like uvicorn, you might wrap the app:
class LifespanMiddleware:
    def __init__(self, app):
        self.app = app

    async def __call__(self, scope, receive, send):
        if scope["type"] == "lifespan":
            message = await receive()
            if message["type"] == "lifespan.startup":
                await broker.start()
                await send({"type": "lifespan.startup.complete"})
            elif message["type"] == "lifespan.shutdown":
                await broker.close()
                await send({"type": "lifespan.shutdown.complete"})
            return
        await self.app(scope, receive, send)


app = LifespanMiddleware(app)
```

TITLE: Parsing Security Configuration for Confluent Kafka in Python
DESCRIPTION: This function parses security-related parameters for Confluent Kafka connections, handling authentication mechanisms, SSL configurations, and security protocols. It returns a dictionary of configuration settings suitable for establishing secure Kafka connections.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/confluent/security/parse_security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def parse_security(  # noqa: C901
    bootstrap_servers: str | list[str],
    security_protocol: str | None = None,
    sasl_mechanism: str | None = None,
    sasl_plain_username: str | None = None,
    sasl_plain_password: str | None = None,
    sasl_kerberos_service_name: str | None = None,
    sasl_kerberos_domain_name: str | None = None,
    sasl_oauth_token_provider: object | None = None,
    ssl_context: object | None = None,
    ssl_check_hostname: bool = True,
    ssl_cafile: str | None = None,
    ssl_certfile: str | None = None,
    ssl_keyfile: str | None = None,
    ssl_password: str | None = None,
    ssl_crlfile: str | None = None,
    ssl_ciphers: str | None = None,
) -> dict[str, Any]:
    """
    Parse security configuration.

    Args:
        bootstrap_servers: Kafka bootstrap servers.
        security_protocol: Protocol used to communicate with brokers.
            Valid values are: PLAINTEXT, SSL, SASL_PLAINTEXT, SASL_SSL.
            Default: PLAINTEXT.
        sasl_mechanism: Authentication mechanism when security_protocol
            is SASL_PLAINTEXT or SASL_SSL. Valid values are: PLAIN,
            GSSAPI, SCRAM-SHA-256, SCRAM-SHA-512, OAUTHBEARER.
            Default: PLAIN
        sasl_plain_username: username for SASL PLAIN authentication.
        sasl_plain_password: password for SASL PLAIN authentication.
        sasl_kerberos_service_name: Service name to include in GSSAPI
            sasl mechanism handshake. Default: kafka
        sasl_kerberos_domain_name: Kerberos domain name to use in GSSAPI
            sasl mechanism handshake. Default: one of bootstrap servers host name
        sasl_oauth_token_provider: OAuthBearer token provider instance.
        ssl_context: Pre-configured OpenSSL context.
        ssl_check_hostname: Flag to configure whether SSL handshake
            should verify that the certificate matches the broker's hostname.
        ssl_cafile: Optional filename of CA file to use in certificate
            verification.
        ssl_certfile: Optional filename of file in PEM format containing
            the client certificate, as well as any CA certificates needed
            to establish the certificate's authenticity.
        ssl_keyfile: Optional filename containing the client private key.
        ssl_password: Optional password to be used when loading the
            certificate chain.
        ssl_crlfile: Optional filename containing the CRL to check for
            certificate expiration.
        ssl_ciphers: Optional string specifying which OpenSSL cipher suites
            to allow.

    Returns:
        Dict with security configuration parameters.
    """
    conf: dict[str, Any] = {"bootstrap.servers": bootstrap_servers}

    if security_protocol:
        conf["security.protocol"] = security_protocol

    if sasl_mechanism:
        conf["sasl.mechanism"] = sasl_mechanism

    if sasl_plain_username:
        conf["sasl.username"] = sasl_plain_username

    if sasl_plain_password:
        conf["sasl.password"] = sasl_plain_password

    if sasl_kerberos_service_name:
        conf["sasl.kerberos.service.name"] = sasl_kerberos_service_name

    if sasl_kerberos_domain_name:
        conf["sasl.kerberos.domain.name"] = sasl_kerberos_domain_name

    if sasl_oauth_token_provider:
        conf["oauth_cb"] = sasl_oauth_token_provider

    if ssl_context:
        conf["ssl.context"] = ssl_context

    if not ssl_check_hostname:
        conf["ssl.check.hostname"] = "false"

    if ssl_cafile:
        conf["ssl.ca.location"] = ssl_cafile

    if ssl_certfile:
        conf["ssl.certificate.location"] = ssl_certfile

    if ssl_keyfile:
        conf["ssl.key.location"] = ssl_keyfile

    if ssl_password:
        conf["ssl.key.password"] = ssl_password

    if ssl_crlfile:
        conf["ssl.crl.location"] = ssl_crlfile

    if ssl_ciphers:
        conf["ssl.cipher.suites"] = ssl_ciphers

    return conf
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/publishing/object.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream import FastStream, Logger
from faststream.redis import RedisBroker

broker = RedisBroker()
app = FastStream(broker)

publisher = broker.publisher("output")

@publisher
@broker.subscriber("input")
async def on_message(body: str, logger: Logger):
    logger.info(f"Got message: {body}")
    return f"Processed: {body}"
```

TITLE: Compiling NATS Wildcards in Python
DESCRIPTION: Function that compiles a FastStream pattern to a NATS wildcard pattern. It replaces path parameters enclosed in curly braces with the NATS wildcard token (*).
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/nats/schemas/js_stream/compile_nats_wildcard.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def compile_nats_wildcard(pattern: str) -> str:
    """
    Compile FastStream pattern to NATS wildcard pattern.

    Args:
        pattern: FastStream pattern

    Returns:
        NATS wildcard pattern (with `*` instead of `{param}`)
    """
    import re

    return re.sub(r"\{[^\}]+\}", "*", pattern)
```

DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses Jinja2 templating to iterate through a list of team members and display their information in HTML. It includes conditionals to filter users based on their inclusion in the 'team' category.

LANGUAGE: jinja2
CODE:
```

{% for user in people.people %}
    {% if 'team' in user.include %}
        <div class="user">
            <a href="{{ user.github }}" target="_blank">
                <div class="avatar-wrapper">
                    <img src="{{ user.avatar }}"/>
                </div>
                <div class="title">
                    {% if user.name %}{{user.name}}<br/>{% endif %}
                    @{{user.username}}
                </div>
            </a>
        </div>
    {% endif %}
{% endfor %}
</div>
```

TITLE: Using Annotated Aliases in Redis
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use annotated aliases for accessing context objects in Redis with proper typing. This approach provides more explicit type hints for the context objects being accessed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/context/existed.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream.redis import RedisBroker
from faststream.redis.annotations import (
    RedisMessage,
    RedisBroker,
    Redis,
    Logger,
    ContextRepo,
)

# ...

@app.subscriber("test")
async def publisher_handler(
    body: dict,
    broker: RedisBroker,  # access to the broker
    context: ContextRepo,  # access to the context
    logger: Logger,  # access to the logger
    message: RedisMessage,  # access to the raw message
) -> None:
    # now, you can call all the broker methods
    await broker.publish(
        {"hello": "world"},
        "response",
    )

    # also, you can access and write to context
    context.my_field = body["data"]

    # logger already contains a `message_id` tag
    # to link all your logs in one scope
    logger.info("Publisher handler is called!")

    # access to message properties
    print(message.channel)
```

TITLE: Checking if RabbitMQ Exchange Type Supports Routing in Python
DESCRIPTION: This function determines whether a specified RabbitMQ exchange type supports message routing based on routing keys. It returns True for 'direct', 'topic', and 'headers' exchange types which support routing, and False for other types like 'fanout'.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/rabbit/utils/is_routing_exchange.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def is_routing_exchange(exchange_type: str) -> bool:
    """Check if exchange is routing.

    `direct`, `topic` and `headers` exchanges are routing exchanges.
    It means you can provide routing key to send message to specific queue.

    Args:
        exchange_type: RabbitMQ exchange type

    Returns:
        True if exchange is routing
    """
    return exchange_type in ("direct", "topic", "headers")
```

TITLE: Implementing Async Context Manager Middlewares
DESCRIPTION: Example of the new requirement in FastStream 0.5.0rc0 that both subscriber and publisher middlewares should be async context manager types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/release.md#2025-04-22_snippet_31

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from contextlib import asynccontextmanager

@asynccontextmanager
async def subscriber_middleware(msg_body):
    yield msg_body

@asynccontextmanager
async def publisher_middleware(
    msg_to_publish,
    **publish_arguments,
):
    yield msg_to_publish

@broker.subscriber("in", middlewares=(subscriber_middleware,))
@broker.publisher("out", middlewares=(publisher_middleware,))
async def handler():
    ...
```

TITLE: Defining ClassicQueueArgs for RabbitMQ Queue Configuration in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the ClassicQueueArgs class, which encapsulates the configuration options for a classic RabbitMQ queue. It includes various parameters such as queue type, durability, auto-delete behavior, and more.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/rabbit/schemas/queue/ClassicQueueArgs.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class ClassicQueueArgs(QueueArgs):
    """Arguments for queue.declare (classic queues)."""

    x_max_length: Optional[int] = None
    x_max_length_bytes: Optional[int] = None
    x_overflow: Optional[str] = None
    x_dead_letter_exchange: Optional[str] = None
    x_dead_letter_routing_key: Optional[str] = None
    x_max_priority: Optional[int] = None
    x_queue_mode: Optional[str] = None
    x_queue_version: Optional[int] = None
    x_max_in_memory_length: Optional[int] = None
    x_max_in_memory_bytes: Optional[int] = None
    x_dead_letter_strategy: Optional[str] = None
    x_single_active_consumer: Optional[bool] = None

    def __init__(
        self,
        queue_type: Literal["classic", "quorum", "stream"] = "classic",
        durable: bool = True,
        auto_delete: bool = False,
        exclusive: bool = False,
        passive: bool = False,
        **kwargs: Any,
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(
            queue_type=queue_type,
            durable=durable,
            auto_delete=auto_delete,
            exclusive=exclusive,
            passive=passive,
            **kwargs,
        )

    def dict(self, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        d = super().dict(*args, **kwargs)
        if self.queue_type != "classic":
            raise ValueError("ClassicQueueArgs can only be used with classic queues")
        return d
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with Litestar
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to integrate a FastStream broker with the Litestar framework using lifecycle hooks. The broker is initialized at application startup and closed during shutdown.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/integrations/frameworks/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from litestar import Litestar
from litestar.lifecycle import on_shutdown, on_startup

from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

broker = KafkaBroker()


@on_startup
async def startup() -> None:
    await broker.start()


@on_shutdown
async def shutdown() -> None:
    await broker.close()


app = Litestar(lifespan=[startup, shutdown])
```

TITLE: Integrating FastStream with Blacksheep
DESCRIPTION: Using FastStream MQBrokers with Blacksheep by starting and stopping them according to the application's lifespan, allowing for message broker interaction in a Blacksheep web application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/faststream.md#2025-04-22_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from blacksheep import Application, get

from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker

broker = KafkaBroker("localhost:9092")
app = Application()


@broker.subscriber("input")
async def handle(msg: str) -> None:
    print(msg)


@get("/")
async def push():
    await broker.publish("Hello World!", "input")
    return {"status": "sent"}


@app.on_start
async def startup(app):
    # Startup the broker
    await broker.start()


@app.on_stop
async def shutdown(app):
    # Shutdown the broker
    await broker.close()
```

TITLE: Defining Server Schema in FastStream AsyncAPI
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the Server class for FastStream's AsyncAPI schema. It includes properties such as url, protocol, protocolVersion, description, variables, security, and bindings.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/asyncapi/schema/Server.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class Server(BaseModel):
    """AsyncAPI server object."""

    url: str = Field(..., description="Server URL.")
    protocol: str = Field(..., description="Server protocol.")
    protocolVersion: Optional[str] = Field(
        None, description="Version of the protocol used."
    )
    description: Optional[str] = Field(None, description="Server description.")
    variables: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = Field(
        None, description="Server variables."
    )
    security: Optional[List[Dict[str, List[str]]]] = Field(
        None, description="Server security requirements."
    )
    bindings: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = Field(
        None, description="Protocol-specific information."
    )
```

TITLE: Parsing Kafka Security Configuration in Python
DESCRIPTION: The parse_security function processes security configurations for Kafka connections, handling different authentication mechanisms. It accepts security settings as input and returns a dictionary with properly formatted security configuration for Kafka client.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/kafka/security/parse_security.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def parse_security(
    security: Optional[SecurityT] = None,
) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """Parse security settings."""
    if security is None:
        return {}

    if isinstance(security, dict):
        return {**security}

    if isinstance(security, str):
        security = SecurityProtocol(security)

    if isinstance(security, SecurityProtocol):
        protocol = str(security.value).lower()

        return {"security_protocol": protocol}
```

TITLE: Using apply_types with Regular Functions
DESCRIPTION: Examples of using the apply_types decorator with regular synchronous and asynchronous functions in FastStream.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/dependencies/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream import Depends, apply_types

def simple_dependency(a: int, b: int = 3) -> int:
    return a + b

@apply_types
def method(a: int, d: int = Depends(simple_dependency)):
    return a + d

assert method("1") == 5
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream import Depends, apply_types
import asyncio

async def simple_dependency(a: int, b: int = 3) -> int:
    return a + b

@apply_types
async def method(a: int, d: int = Depends(simple_dependency)):
    return a + d

assert asyncio.run(method("1")) == 5
```

TITLE: Importing Application Module Dynamically in FastStream CLI
DESCRIPTION: The `try_import_app` function attempts to import a FastStream application by its module path. It handles various import errors gracefully, providing specific error messages for different failure scenarios such as module not found or import errors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/cli/utils/imports/try_import_app.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from importlib import import_module
from pathlib import Path
from types import ModuleType
from typing import Any, Optional, Union


def try_import_app(app_path: str) -> Any:
    """Try to import application from file path.

    Args:
        app_path: string path to importing application

    Raises:
        ModuleNotFoundError: If application module can not be found
        ImportError: If application module can not be imported

    Returns:
        Any: Imported application
    """
    try:
        if Path(app_path).exists():
            app_name = app_path.rsplit("/", 1)[-1]
            if app_name.endswith(".py"):
                app_name = app_name[:-3].replace("/", ".")
                directory = str(Path(app_path).parent.absolute())
                import sys

                sys.path.insert(0, directory)
                try:
                    module = import_module(app_name)
                finally:
                    sys.path.pop(0)
                return module
            raise ImportError("Only `.py` files can be imported")
        else:
            module = import_module(app_path)
            return module
    except (ImportError, ModuleNotFoundError) as e:
        module_name = app_path.split(":")[0]
        try:
            import_module(module_name)
        except ModuleNotFoundError:
            raise ModuleNotFoundError(
                f"Module `{module_name}` not found."
            ) from e
        except ImportError:
            raise ImportError(
                f"Can not import from `{module_name}` module"
            ) from e
        raise ImportError(f"Can not import from `{app_path}` path") from e
```

TITLE: Defining LogicPublisher Class for Redis in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the LogicPublisher class, which is used for publishing messages to Redis streams in FastStream. It includes methods for publishing messages and managing the connection to Redis.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/redis/publisher/usecase/LogicPublisher.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class LogicPublisher(AsyncPublisher, BaseLogicPublisher):
    """Redis publisher."""

    def __init__(
        self,
        redis: Redis,
        encoder: Optional[Callable[[Any], bytes]] = None,
        serializer: Optional[Callable[[Any], Any]] = None,
    ) -> None:
        """Initialize Redis publisher.

        Args:
            redis: Redis client
            encoder: Message encoder
            serializer: Message serializer
        """
        self.redis = redis
        self.encoder = encoder or self._encode
        self.serializer = serializer or self._serialize

    async def publish(
        self,
        message: Any,
        *,
        stream: str,
        maxlen: Optional[int] = None,
        approximate: bool = True,
    ) -> bytes:
        """Publish message to Redis stream.

        Args:
            message: Message to publish
            stream: Stream name
            maxlen: Maximum length of the stream
            approximate: Whether to use approximate trimming

        Returns:
            Message ID
        """
        serialized = self.serializer(message)
        encoded = self.encoder(serialized)
        return await self.redis.xadd(
            stream,
            {b"message": encoded},
            maxlen=maxlen,
            approximate=approximate,
        )

    @staticmethod
    def _encode(message: Any) -> bytes:
        """Encode message to bytes.

        Args:
            message: Message to encode

        Returns:
            Encoded message
        """
        return orjson.dumps(message)

    @staticmethod
    def _serialize(message: Any) -> Any:
        """Serialize message.

        Args:
            message: Message to serialize

        Returns:
            Serialized message
        """
        return message
```

TITLE: Accessing Pattern Data in Redis Channel Subscription with FastStream
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to access pattern data encoded in Redis channel names using FastStream. It shows how to extract and use data from the channel name in the message handler function.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/redis/pubsub/subscription.md#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream import FastStream
from faststream.redis import RedisBroker, PubSub

broker = RedisBroker()
app = FastStream(broker)

@broker.subscriber(channel=PubSub("test.*", pattern=True))
async def on_message(msg: str, logger, channel: str):
    _, category = channel.split(".", 1)
    logger.info(f"Received message in category '{category}': {msg}")

@broker.subscriber(channel=PubSub("user.*.status", pattern=True))
async def on_status_update(msg: str, logger, channel: str):
    _, user_id, _ = channel.split(".", 2)
    logger.info(f"User {user_id} status updated: {msg}")
```

TITLE: Defining Header Class for FastStream Context Management in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the Header class, which is part of FastStream's context management utilities. It provides methods for managing request headers, including setting, getting, and deleting header values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/utils/context/Header.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class Header:
    """Request header wrapper"""

    def __init__(self, headers: dict[str, str] | None = None) -> None:
        self._headers = headers or {}

    def __getitem__(self, key: str) -> str:
        return self._headers[key]

    def __setitem__(self, key: str, value: str) -> None:
        self._headers[key] = value

    def __delitem__(self, key: str) -> None:
        del self._headers[key]

    def __contains__(self, key: str) -> bool:
        return key in self._headers

    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator[str]:
        return iter(self._headers)

    def __len__(self) -> int:
        return len(self._headers)

    def __repr__(self) -> str:
        return f"Header({self._headers})"

    def get(self, key: str, default: str | None = None) -> str | None:
        return self._headers.get(key, default)

    def items(self) -> ItemsView[str, str]:
        return self._headers.items()

    def keys(self) -> KeysView[str]:
        return self._headers.keys()

    def values(self) -> ValuesView[str]:
        return self._headers.values()

    def pop(self, key: str, default: str | None = None) -> str | None:
        return self._headers.pop(key, default)

    def clear(self) -> None:
        self._headers.clear()

    def update(self, other: dict[str, str] | None = None, **kwargs: str) -> None:
        if other is not None:
            self._headers.update(other)
        self._headers.update(kwargs)
```

TITLE: Using Annotated Aliases in Confluent
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use annotated aliases for accessing context objects in Confluent Kafka with proper typing. This approach provides more explicit type hints for the context objects being accessed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/context/existed.md#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from faststream.confluent import KafkaBroker
from faststream.confluent.annotations import (
    KafkaMessage,
    KafkaBroker,
    KafkaProducer,
    Logger,
    ContextRepo,
)

# ...

@app.subscriber("test")
async def publisher_handler(
    body: dict,
    broker: KafkaBroker,  # access to the broker
    context: ContextRepo,  # access to the context
    logger: Logger,  # access to the logger
    message: KafkaMessage,  # access to the raw message
) -> None:
    # now, you can call all the broker methods
    await broker.publish(
        {"hello": "world"},
        "response",
    )

    # also, you can access and write to context
    context.my_field = body["data"]

    # logger already contains a `message_id` tag
    # to link all your logs in one scope
    logger.info("Publisher handler is called!")

    # access to message properties
    print(message.offset)
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class ListBatchPublisher(BaseBatchPublisher):
    def __init__(
        self,
        url: str = "redis://localhost:6379",
        *,
        max_batch_size: int = 10,
        flush_interval: float = 1,
        max_queue_size: int = 10_000,
        client: Optional[Redis] = None,
        **kwargs: Any,
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(
            max_batch_size=max_batch_size,
            flush_interval=flush_interval,
            max_queue_size=max_queue_size,
        )
        self.client = client or Redis.from_url(url, **kwargs)
```

TITLE: Manual Local Context Management in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: Shows manual management of local context using set_local, get_local, and reset_local methods within the current call stack, with logging function demonstrating context access.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/context/custom.md#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from contextlib import suppress
from faststream import FastStream
from faststream.kafka import KafkaBroker
from faststream import context

broker = KafkaBroker()


async def log_request():
    # access local context value
    with suppress(KeyError):
        request_id = context.get_local("request_id")
        print(f"Processing request: {request_id}")


@broker.subscriber("test")
async def handle_message(body: str):
    # Set local context
    context.set_local("request_id", "12345")

    # access local context value
    await log_request()

    # Clear local context
    context.reset_local("request_id")

    # Context is cleared
    await log_request()


app = FastStream(broker)
```

TITLE: Defining LogicPublisher Class for FastStream Confluent Integration
DESCRIPTION: The LogicPublisher class implementation that extends BasePublisher to provide Confluent Kafka-specific publishing capabilities. It manages connection to Kafka topics and handles message serialization and delivery.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/confluent/publisher/usecase/LogicPublisher.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class LogicPublisher(BasePublisher):
    """Confluent publisher that handles sending messages to Kafka."""

    def __init__(
        self,
        *,
        topic: str,
        serializer: ConfluentSerializer,
        partition: Optional[int] = None,
        key: Optional[str] = None,
        headers: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None,
        middlewares: Optional[List] = None,
        **__,
    ) -> None:
        """Initialize a Confluent publisher.

        Args:
            topic: The topic to publish to.
            serializer: The serializer to use for messages.
            partition: The partition to publish to. Defaults to None, which means the partitioner will decide.
            key: The key to use for messages. Defaults to None.
            headers: The headers to use for messages. Defaults to None.
            middlewares: List of middlewares to apply to the publisher.
        """
        super().__init__(middlewares=middlewares)
        self.topic = topic
        self.partition = partition
        self.key = key
        self.headers = headers
        self.serializer = serializer

    async def publish(
        self,
        message: SendableMessage,
        *,
        topic: Optional[str] = None,
        key: Optional[str] = None,
        partition: Optional[int] = None,
        headers: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None,
        **__,
    ) -> None:
        """Publish a message to Kafka.

        Args:
            message: The message to publish.
            topic: The topic to publish to. Defaults to the publisher's topic.
            key: The key to use for the message. Defaults to the publisher's key.
            partition: The partition to publish to. Defaults to the publisher's partition.
            headers: The headers to use for the message. Defaults to the publisher's headers.
        """
        to_publish = self.apply_middlewares(message)

        serialized = await self.serializer.serialize(
            to_publish if not isinstance(to_publish, ConfluentMessage) else to_publish.model_dump()
            if hasattr(to_publish, "model_dump")
            else model_to_dict(to_publish)
            if hasattr(to_publish, "__pydantic_fields_set__")
            else to_publish
        )

        kwargs = {}
        if key or self.key:
            kwargs["key"] = key or self.key
        if partition or self.partition:
            kwargs["partition"] = partition or self.partition
        if headers or self.headers:
            kwargs["headers"] = headers or self.headers

        await self.serializer.producer.send_and_wait(
            topic or self.topic,
            serialized,
            **kwargs,
        )
```

TITLE: Contact Class Definition in FastStream AsyncAPI Schema
DESCRIPTION: The Contact class defines contact information for an AsyncAPI specification. It extends Pydantic's BaseModel and includes fields for name, url, and email with their respective validators.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/asyncapi/schema/info/Contact.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class Contact(BaseModel):
    """Contact information for the exposed API."""

    name: Optional[str] = None
    """The identifying name of the contact person/organization."""

    url: Optional[AnyUrl] = None
    """The URL pointing to the contact information. MUST be in the format of a URL."""

    email: Optional[EmailStr] = None
    """The email address of the contact person/organization. MUST be in the format of an email address."""

    @field_validator("email", mode="before")
    @classmethod
    def validate_email(cls, email: str) -> str:
        if not email:
            return email

        try:
            validate_email(email)
        except InvalidEmail as e:
            raise ValueError(f"Invalid email: {e}") from e

        return email
```

TITLE: Defining FastStream CLI Main Run Function in Python
DESCRIPTION: This function is the entry point for the FastStream CLI. It sets up the application, handles command-line arguments, and initializes the FastStream application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/cli/main/run.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def run(
    app: str,
    controller: str | None = None,
    host: str = "127.0.0.1",
    port: int = 8000,
    reload: bool = False,
    workers: int = 1,
    log_level: str = "info",
    log_config: str | None = None,
    env_file: str | None = None,
) -> None:
    """Run the FastStream application.

    Args:
        app (str): The FastStream application to run.
        controller (str | None, optional): The controller to use. Defaults to None.
        host (str, optional): The host to bind to. Defaults to "127.0.0.1".
        port (int, optional): The port to bind to. Defaults to 8000.
        reload (bool, optional): Whether to reload the application on code changes. Defaults to False.
        workers (int, optional): The number of worker processes. Defaults to 1.
        log_level (str, optional): The log level. Defaults to "info".
        log_config (str | None, optional): The log configuration file. Defaults to None.
        env_file (str | None, optional): The environment file to load. Defaults to None.
    """
    import uvicorn
    from faststream.cli.utils import import_from_string, load_env

    load_env(env_file)

    app = import_from_string(app)
    if controller:
        controller = import_from_string(controller)
        app = controller(app)

    uvicorn.run(
        app,
        host=host,
        port=port,
        reload=reload,
        workers=workers,
        log_level=log_level,
        log_config=log_config,
    )
```

TITLE: Processing messages with context management in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: The process_msg utility function handles the entire message processing workflow in FastStream, including setting up context, executing the handler function, managing acknowledgment and error handling. It supports both sync and async handler functions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/broker/utils/process_msg.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
async def process_msg(
    message: AbstractMessage,
    ctx: AbstractContext,
    handler: object,
    fn_args: list,
    fn_kwargs: dict,
    timeout: Optional[float] = None,
    retry: Optional[Retry] = None,
    middlewares: Optional[list[Callable]] = None,
) -> None:
    """Process message by handler."""
    awaited = False

    task_timeout: Any = False if timeout is None else timeout

    def on_timeout() -> NoReturn:
        msg = f"Handler process timeout: {timeout} seconds"
        raise TimeoutError(msg)

    async def handle_process() -> Any:
        nonlocal awaited

        try:
            orig_ctx = context.set(ctx)
            orig_msg = message_context.set(message)

            try:
                handler_result = None

                middlewares_f = middlewares or []

                # apply middlewares
                chain = reduce(
                    lambda x, f: wrap_fn(f, x),
                    middlewares_f,
                    handler,
                )

                # call functions
                handler_result = chain(*fn_args, **fn_kwargs)

                if isawaitable(handler_result):
                    awaited = True
                    return await handler_result
                return handler_result
            finally:
                context.reset(orig_ctx)
                message_context.reset(orig_msg)
        except Exception:
            if retry:
                retry_count = message.retry_count + 1 if message.retry_count else 1

                if retry_count <= retry.retries:
                    message.retry_count = retry_count
                    await message.nack()

                    return

            if message.decoded_error:
                ctx._raise_for_status(message)  # noqa: SLF001
            raise

    try:
        handler_result: Any = None

        if task_timeout is not False:
            try:
                handler_result = await asyncio.wait_for(
                    handle_process(),
                    timeout=task_timeout,
                    loop=asyncio.get_event_loop(),
                )
            except TimeoutError:
                on_timeout()
        else:
            handler_result = await handle_process()

        if not message.is_nacked and not message.is_acked:
            await message.ack()

        if isinstance(handler_result, tuple) and len(handler_result) == 2:
            # In case handler returns response message and status
            return handler_result
        return handler_result, None
    except Exception as e:
        if not message.is_nacked and not message.is_acked:
            await message.nack()
        raise e
```

TITLE: Reusing Original Decoder for AIOKafka in FastStream
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a custom decoder that reuses the original decoder function for AIOKafka messages. It includes type hints for the original decoder callback.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/serialization/decoder.md#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from types import Callable, Awaitable
from faststream.types import DecodedMessage
from faststream.kafka import KafkaMessage

async def decoder(
    msg: KafkaMessage,
    original_decoder: Callable[[KafkaMessage], Awaitable[DecodedMessage]],
) -> DecodedMessage:
    return await original_decoder(msg)
```

TITLE: Defining ContextRepo Class in Python for FastStream
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the ContextRepo class, which is used for managing context in FastStream applications. It includes methods for getting, setting, and removing context, as well as handling context stacks.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/utils/context/ContextRepo.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class ContextRepo:
    """Context repository.

    Args:
        context (dict): Initial context
    """

    def __init__(self, context: dict[str, Any] | None = None) -> None:
        self._context: dict[str, Any] = context or {}
        self._context_stack: list[dict[str, Any]] = []

    def get(self, key: str, default: Any = None) -> Any:
        """Get value from context.

        Args:
            key (str): Key to get
            default (Any, optional): Default value. Defaults to None.

        Returns:
            Any: Value from context
        """
        return self._context.get(key, default)

    def set(self, key: str, value: Any) -> None:
        """Set value to context.

        Args:
            key (str): Key to set
            value (Any): Value to set
        """
        self._context[key] = value

    def remove(self, key: str) -> None:
        """Remove value from context.

        Args:
            key (str): Key to remove
        """
        self._context.pop(key, None)

    def push(self) -> None:
        """Push context to stack."""
        self._context_stack.append(self._context.copy())

    def pop(self) -> None:
        """Pop context from stack."""
        if self._context_stack:
            self._context = self._context_stack.pop()

    def clear(self) -> None:
        """Clear context."""
        self._context.clear()
        self._context_stack.clear()

    def update(self, context: dict[str, Any]) -> None:
        """Update context.

        Args:
            context (dict): Context to update
        """
        self._context.update(context)

    def copy(self) -> dict[str, Any]:
        """Copy context.

        Returns:
            dict: Copy of context
        """
        return self._context.copy()

    def __getitem__(self, key: str) -> Any:
        return self._context[key]

    def __setitem__(self, key: str, value: Any) -> None:
        self._context[key] = value

    def __delitem__(self, key: str) -> None:
        del self._context[key]

    def __contains__(self, key: str) -> bool:
        return key in self._context

    def __len__(self) -> int:
        return len(self._context)

    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator[str]:
        return iter(self._context)

    def __repr__(self) -> str:
        return f"{self.__class__.__name__}({self._context!r})"
```

TITLE: Retrieving FastStream Documentation Application
DESCRIPTION: Function that retrieves or generates FastStream documentation based on provided parameters. It handles importing documentation modules, creating temporary documentation files, and configuring FastAPI routes for serving the documentation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/cli/docs/app/serve.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def get_documentation_app(
    docs_module: str | None,
    app_path: str | None,
    app_var: str | None,
    title: str | None,
    app: Any,
    templates: Any,
    tmpdir: str,
) -> tuple[Any, str]:
    """Get documentation application.

    Args:
        docs_module: module with docs configuration
        app_path: path to the application module
        app_var: application variable name
        title: API title
        app: FastAPI application
        templates: Jinja2Templates
        tmpdir: temporary directory

    Returns:
        tuple with FastAPI application and url path
    """
    import sys
    from pathlib import Path
    import importlib.util
    import importlib
    from typing import Dict, Any, List

    from fastapi import Request

    markdown_js = Path(__file__).parent / "templates" / "static" / "js" / "markdown.js"

    url_path = "/docs"

    if docs_module:
        # If docs_module is provided, load it and use its documentation
        try:
            module = importlib.import_module(docs_module)
        except ImportError:
            module_path = Path(docs_module)
            if not module_path.exists():
                print(f"Module {docs_module} not found")
                sys.exit(1)

            module_name = module_path.stem
            spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, module_path)
            if not spec or not spec.loader:
                print(f"Failed to load module {docs_module}")
                sys.exit(1)

            module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(spec)
            sys.modules[module_name] = module
            spec.loader.exec_module(module)

        url_path = getattr(module, "URL_PATH", url_path)

        @app.get(url_path)
        async def get_docs(request: Request) -> Any:
            return templates.TemplateResponse(
                "docs.html",
                {
                    "request": request,
                    "specs": getattr(module, "SPECS", []),
                    "title": getattr(module, "TITLE", "FastStream API"),
                    "description": getattr(module, "DESCRIPTION", ""),
                    "favicon": getattr(module, "FAVICON", None),
                    "swagger_js_url": getattr(
                        module, "SWAGGER_JS_URL", "/static/js/swagger-ui-bundle.js"
                    ),
                    "swagger_css_url": getattr(
                        module, "SWAGGER_CSS_URL", "/static/css/swagger-ui.css"
                    ),
                    "redoc_js_url": getattr(
                        module, "REDOC_JS_URL", "/static/js/redoc.standalone.js"
                    ),
                    "markdown_js_url": getattr(
                        module, "MARKDOWN_JS_URL", "/static/js/markdown.js"
                    ),
                    "markdown_css_url": getattr(
                        module, "MARKDOWN_CSS_URL", "/static/css/markdown.css"
                    ),
                    "rapidoc_js_url": getattr(
                        module, "RAPIDOC_JS_URL", "/static/js/rapidoc-min.js"
                    ),
                    "element_js_url": getattr(
                        module, "ELEMENT_JS_URL", "/static/js/elements.js"
                    ),
                },
            )
    elif app_path:
        # If app_path is provided, create a temporary OpenAPI specs file
        # and configure it in FastAPI
        import json
        import os
        import sys
        from faststream._compat import PYDANTIC_V2

        if PYDANTIC_V2:
            from pydantic import TypeAdapter
        else:
            from pydantic import parse_obj_as

        from faststream.cli.run import load_app

        imported_app = load_app(app_path, app_var)

        if isinstance(title, str):
            imported_app.title = title

        specs = imported_app.schema.model_dump() if PYDANTIC_V2 else imported_app.schema.dict()

        specs_path = os.path.join(tmpdir, "openapi.json")
        with open(specs_path, "w") as f:
            json.dump(specs, f)

        @app.get(url_path)
        async def get_docs(request: Request) -> Any:
            with open(specs_path, "r") as f:
                specs = json.load(f)

            return templates.TemplateResponse(
                "docs.html",
                {
                    "request": request,
                    "specs": [{
                        "type": "openapi",
                        "url": "/openapi.json",
                        "title": specs.get("title", "FastStream API"),
                    }],
                    "title": specs.get("title", "FastStream API"),
                    "description": specs.get("description", ""),
                    "favicon": None,
                    "swagger_js_url": "/static/js/swagger-ui-bundle.js",
                    "swagger_css_url": "/static/css/swagger-ui.css",
                    "redoc_js_url": "/static/js/redoc.standalone.js",
                    "markdown_js_url": "/static/js/markdown.js",
                    "markdown_css_url": "/static/css/markdown.css",
                    "rapidoc_js_url": "/static/js/rapidoc-min.js",
                    "element_js_url": "/static/js/elements.js",
                },
            )

        @app.get("/openapi.json")
        async def get_openapi() -> Any:
            with open(specs_path, "r") as f:
                return json.load(f)
    else:
        # If no docs_module or app_path is provided, show default documentation page
        @app.get(url_path)
        async def get_docs(request: Request) -> Any:
            return templates.TemplateResponse(
                "docs.html",
                {
                    "request": request,
                    "specs": [],
                    "title": title or "FastStream API",
                    "description": "",
                    "favicon": None,
                    "swagger_js_url": "/static/js/swagger-ui-bundle.js",
                    "swagger_css_url": "/static/css/swagger-ui.css",
                    "redoc_js_url": "/static/js/redoc.standalone.js",
                    "markdown_js_url": "/static/js/markdown.js",
                    "markdown_css_url": "/static/css/markdown.css",
                    "rapidoc_js_url": "/static/js/rapidoc-min.js",
                    "element_js_url": "/static/js/elements.js",
                },
            )

    return app, url_path
```

TITLE: Using Annotated with Context in Redis
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use Python's Annotated feature with FastStream Context in Redis. This approach is similar to pytest fixtures, allowing for cleaner dependency injection with type hints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/getting-started/context/index.md#2025-04-22_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from typing import Annotated

from faststream import FastStream, Context, Logger
from faststream.redis import RedisBroker


broker = RedisBroker()
app = FastStream(broker)


# inject application object from a Context
LoggerDep = Annotated[Logger, Context()]
BrokerDep = Annotated[RedisBroker, Context()]


@broker.subscriber("test")
async def base_handler(
    broker: BrokerDep,  # from context with annotation
    logger: LoggerDep,  # from context with annotation
    msg: str,
):
    logger.info("I got a message!")
    await broker.publish(msg, "answer")
```

TITLE: Displaying Section Experts using Jinja2 and HTML
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to display experts for specific sections (Kafka, RabbitMQ, NATS, Redis) using Jinja2 templating and HTML. It filters users based on their inclusion in each section's category.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/faststream-people.md#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jinja2
CODE:
```
<div class="user-list user-list-center">
{% for user in people.people %}
    {% if 'kafka' in user.include %}
        <div class="user">
            <a href="{{ user.github }}" target="_blank">
                <div class="avatar-wrapper">
                    <img src="{{ user.avatar }}"/>
                </div>
                <div class="title">
                    {% if user.name %}{{user.name}}<br/>{% endif %}
                    @{{user.username}}
                </div>
            </a>
        </div>
    {% endif %}
{% endfor %}
</div>
```

TITLE: Publishing Messages with FastStream CLI
DESCRIPTION: The `publish_message` function provides a command-line interface for publishing messages to a message broker. It supports multiple broker types, custom headers, and various payload formats including JSON.
SOURCE: https://github.com/ag2ai/faststream/blob/main/docs/docs/en/api/faststream/cli/main/publish_message.md#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def publish_message(
    broker: str,
    url: str,
    target: str,
    message: str = None,
    file: IO[str] = None,
    content_type: str = None,
    header: list[str] = None,
):
    """Publish message to broker.

    Args:
        broker: broker type
        url: broker URL
        target: broker target address
        message: message to publish
        file: file with message to publish
        content_type: message content type
        header: message headers
    """
    from faststream.cli import serializers

    if message and file:
        typer.echo("You can't use both message and file")
        raise typer.Exit(1)

    if not (message or file):
        typer.echo("You must specify message or file")
        raise typer.Exit(1)

    if file:
        message = file.read()

    # If the message is a json string, parse it
    if content_type == "application/json":
        try:
            message = json.loads(message)
        except json.JSONDecodeError:
            typer.echo("Invalid JSON")
            raise typer.Exit(1)

    # Parse headers
    headers = {}
    if header:
        for h in header:
            try:
                k, v = h.split("=")
                headers[k] = v
            except ValueError:
                typer.echo(f"Invalid header: {h}")
                raise typer.Exit(1)

    # Fix types
    payload = message
    if content_type is not None and content_type in serializers.CONTENT_TYPES:
        payload = serializers.CONTENT_TYPES[content_type](payload)

    broker_package = import_module(f"faststream.{broker}")
    with getattr(broker_package, pascalcase(broker))(url) as broker_client:
        broker_client.publish(payload, target, headers=headers)
```
